text: Made with exotic sapphires, crafted into the shape of the flesh-eating Khepra beetle, this brooch protects the wearer from any baleful magic directed against them.
The simple clay vessel may not look like much, but the High Priest's Undying essence within can thwart sorcery and strengthen incantations.
These eight magical scrolls, containing the sum total of Neferra's lifetime of learning, can whip up an unstoppable hurricane of power to crush the foe.
Created by the Arch-Necromancer, the staff harnesses Dark Magic from deep within the accursed Black Pyramid.
All of Nehekhara's gods and goddesses are inscribed along the ancient copper staff, granting Khatep mastery over their latent magical power.
Those who don this enchanted plate armour gain Geheb's strength and favour, enabling them to parry a normally-lethal blow with a seemingly-lucky deflection.
This helm, inscribed with an invocation to the malign Desert-God, so that his savage ferocity may overtake its wearer.
…and their vestments shall contain a writing which no man knoweth.
Forged from bronze, cooled in the blood of the giant Lybrasian scorpion, and gilded in red and Lahmian gold, this ancient breastplate will turn aside all but the strongest of blows.
This armour imbues its wearer with the ability to continue fighting even when mortally wounded.
This mystical shield channels white-hot energy from the Sun-God, unleashing it in a blinding flash of light.
This small, blue cap is adorned with prayers to Neru, so she may have special care for its wearer's precious head.
These ornate armour plates are decorated with the likeness of the Scorpion-God; his protective energies pervade the very metal used, offering additional protection to the wearer.
The elaborate piece of jewellery hampers the effectiveness of Dark Magic ranged against it.
The desert itself shall be your coat... and the foe's undoing.

One sip of the elixir fills the body of its drinker with the strength of many powerful, elite warriors.
Death's foul taint hangs heavy from Prince Kharnut's elaborate deathmask, gripping the hearts of those who gaze upon it and freezing them in terror.
Sealed and bound with powerful glyphs, this jar contains the remains of a Liche Priest and all the magical energy at his command.
This Hero's victories are recorded on a mighty totemic pole that pulses with an aura of greatness.
This charmed helmet, fashioned from the skull of a slaughtered foe, protects Tretch from blows of all kinds, be they physical or magical.
The coils of the serpent wind around its prey, injecting its venom and granting its bearer regenerative abilities.
This dark, ragged shroud is imbued with Sokth's treacherous essence, enabling them to stalk their enemies unseen until the final moment.
Effectively several crowns in one, this regal headdress instils Settra's unyielding will within those nearby who serve him.
Infused with the sun's dazzling intensity, the power harnessed within gleams brilliantly, blinding the wearer's opponents.
Treachery - and indeed scorpion-husbandry - can be taught and learned like many other skills.
The man who designed the Tomb Kings' elaborate crypts and vaults was just far too skilled to be allowed to rest in his own.
Bearing witness to men's downfall, he judges their worthiness to serve his master-deity from beyond the grave.
What courageous heart has he who serves the God of Earth and Strength.
The Ushabti of Djaf's Messengers fought with legendary zeal, even as the odds against them grew.
The arrows of the Hawk Legion of Khemri always found their mark at necks, groins and the tiniest chinks in enemy armour.
With gilded bones and magically-honed blades, the Golden Host of Mahrak were the glory of the Third Dynasty.
Knowing precisely where to place the killing blow, Rasetra's Crocodile Squadron turned swordplay into an art form.
Blessed by Sokth himself, the Scorpion Guard could shrug off mortal blows and carve through infantry with horrifying efficiency.
Beguiling and deceptive, the Sphinx Legion of Numas caught countless foes unprepared, even in the open field.
With the Vulture-God Ualatp at their backs, the Zandri Blackshields drove their chariots with preternatural speed.
Khemri's noble class still possess much of their former presence and power, even after death.
This knot of life at once untie: poor venomous fool, be angry and dispatch.

Where once he dug graves, now he toils eternally.

An imposing monument to Nehekhara's former power, now living once again in service of its Lords.

This sigil, carved into the war chariot of King Rah-Nutt, caused arrows and spears glance harmlessly away as he rode into battle.
This powerful item contains just enough essence from a malevolent elemental spirit to weaken the foe's magical attack.
This precious stone glows with the rising of the sun, gifting its bearer with the Great Father's divine protection.
This Tomb Prince's magical sword draws lifeforce from the slain to imbue the body of its wielder with stolen essence.

The very late King Setep's ornamented, curved sword shimmers with a blue hue that shatters the foe's armour.
All in the presence of these weapons' bearer are strangely humbled by the aura of majesty they convey.
This enchanted, impossibly-sharp blade can cleave through armour, flesh, bone and souls with equal ease, reducing victims to a lifeless husk.
This enchanted stave is blessed by Neru, Goddess of the Moon, who comes each night to protect the sons of the gods.
A spell of enchantment gives this cudgel, gilded with precious stones, additional power - as if any were needed!
Beware the venomous bite of the Cobra-God.
This deceptive little blade has some nasty uses that belie its ceremonial origins.
Its curved blade, designed to hook shields, heads and tentacles, is balanced with one blunt edge to quickly batter the entrapped foe to death.
This spear imbues the bearer with the Sky-God's decisiveness when dispensing swift, brutal justice without haste.
Blessed by the God of the Sun, the sword's white-hot edge is infused with the desert's baking heat, setting the air itself ablaze and blinding the foe.
The sword burns away the flesh of Arkhan's victims, leaving nothing but a charred skeleton, bound to the Liche King's dark will for all eternity.
Fashioned into the shape of a striking asp, the staff writhes and spits with the spiteful anger of Asaph, Goddess of Vengeance.
The slaughtered sentinel passes on its natural abilities to the one who killed it; terrified opponents will be consumed by a fiery inferno.
The Phoenix is constantly ablaze with magical flames; when extinguished, this item confers the very same resistance to fire upon the bearer.
A gift from Khaine, containing the secret of eternal youth and beauty. His brides may bathe in it to renew their vitality.

A helmet of older design that is said to imbue its wearer with the courage of the Grungni.
Heavy plate-mail warn by the dedicated guardians and Kingsguard who serve the most ancient Karaks.
The preferred mail of scouts and prospectors alike, this armour is wrought with unique runes of stealth.
Rangers' cloaks are entwined with runes of concealment and warding.
Gold-plated bracelets inscribed with runes that mirror the tattoos of the greatest Slayers to ensure a swift killing blow.

Large iron bands wrapped around the Ironbeard's wrist to deflect enemy strikes.
Said to contain a bottomless mug of Bugman's XXXXXX; not so much a yard of ale, as a league!

A Dawi with a few beers in him is even braver than your average guard!

Bound within this mighty sceptre is the power to move the mountain peaks themselves.
Not only useful for holding up pantaloons and for tucking your beard in, but great for carrying your axe in too.

This weapon has been augmented for improved range and reload time, making it ideal for dealing swiftly with threats of an existential nature!
A mighty axe covered in vengeful runes that's as desperate to fulfil the Slayer Oath as its owner.
Created by Grungni himself, Starbreaker is among the most powerful of all Dawi weapons.
An axe worthy a great Slayer, tempered to break through tough Troll skin.
Veterans have honed their weapons to within a whisker of perfection; they know a hammer's heft, making them perfectly balanced.
This enchanted fan keeps Cylostra cool when the heat is on, improving the recharge of her abilities and reducing their cooldown times.
Fashioned from interlocking tentacles and seashells and permanently dripping with slime, this armour clings to the wearer's body, allowing them to move freely.
Every pirate's favourite, this buckler is layered with Sea-Dragon scales which provide reliable protection yet weigh virtually nothing.
Fortunately, this volume, containing every slight made against the Dawi on the high seas, has been made with runes of waterproofing.

This particular moondial enables its owner to pull off seemingly-impossible feats of navigation and piloting.
The classic pirate brew. It makes one extremely fiery... in every way!

This enchanted talisman is carved from the heart of the largest black tree in the Petrified Forest.
Though the Amulet of Fire constantly flickers with pale flames, the wearer is never burned, and is more resistant to magic.
The bearer of this amethyst amulet knows things no mortal should.
A dark crown, that will ensorcel the heart of those that bear it.
Made from gold of the Blackspine Mountains, the Deathmask depicts Khaine in his aspect of the Deathbringer.
The Emerald Collar is a gold band encrusted with cursed stones.
These pendants are tokens in the form of a simple rat skull strung upon an iron chain. They are 'gifts' from the Council of Thirteen.
An ancient and potent token of protection this necklace wards off attacks and those of spiteful intent.
Few wear the Golden Crown for long; the souls of the dead hang heavy about its brow, despite considerable arcane protections.
Billowing black smoke emerges from the opal set into this ring, obscuring the wearer's position.
The size of the artefact known as the Talisman of Saphery belies its power, negating the effects of enchanted weapons against the bearer.
The amulet is a lustrous polished stone with a midnight hue, engraved with a single spiteful rune.
These golden bracers are fabled to have been found on the shores of distant Lustria and are inscribed with unusual glyphs.
A single green gem adorns the hilt and a terrible poison is smeared upon its blade.
This sword has been left for thirteen days in the dreaded Cauldron of One Thousand Poxes; now a foul green fluid drips from its edge.
Bright blue steel can be enchanted to hold spells of great speed and deadly accuracy; the Elves of Ulthuan are masters of such magic.
To the valiant, this blade lends supernatural speed and vigour; to the craven and corrupt, it brings only swift death.
Smeared with special ointments of the Plaguelords, even a scratch from this blade can cause a lethal infection.
Said to be the weapon wielded by the Old One Tzunki, this exquisitely crafted weapon is unbreakable and hums as it cuts through the air.
The Blade of Ruin is not one to be wielded lightly; its owner stands to lose as much as its victim.
This gleaming blade is found in the watery depths and honed by crashing waves. It strikes with the unstoppable power of the sea itself.
An acrid smell of sulphur exudes from its barbed blades.
A dire lance, etched with the fiery blood of Dragons. It is much feared by High Elf Princes from the realm of Caledor.
This mace has a life of its own; it strikes out with lightning speed to bite enemy weapons before a blow is struck.
This halberd was carried by Lord Khalak of Ghrond, the first Captain of the Black Guard. It has been passed down to every successor since.
Created by Hotek, a renegade priest of Vaul, this blade of obsidian allows the wielder to strike with blinding speed.
This ceremonial dagger has taken thousands of sacrifices to the bloodthirsty Sotek, but there is always a need for more…
A terrible weapon - a lance tipped with a blade carved from Cold One teeth, that leaves ragged wounds ensuring victims bleed painfully to death.
A Skaven weapon forged specifically for killing the hated Beard-things. Die-die!
A large, bladed weapon bound with spells of dismemberment.
This twisted blade was taken from the body of a Chaos Champion. Why he should have carried it not known, along with the name of his Elven slayer.
Heartseeker has an uncanny ability to find the heart of a living thing. Dark Elves delight in its ability to destroy the lifeforce of their victims.
Woe to those who fall within its grasp, for the claw is strong enough to crush a Troll's skull.
An unspeakably powerful weapon once said to have been wielded by the warlike Old One deity, Tlanxla.
Forged by fallen Priests of Vaul and fuelled by the blood of sacrificial victims.
As light as a dagger, this curved blade invigorates the wielder with the power of the sun, fuelling his charge with fiery vigour.
An exquisite sword forged from minerals found in the sea; no matter its wielder, no enemy will get a clean blow.
The tip of this massive spear was carved from the horn of the very first Stegadon to bear a war howdah.
When this sword is unsheathed, a strange buzzing hum is heard forewarning the bearer of his enemy's attack.
Brought to the world by the Old Ones, this weapon shimmers in and out of existence, severing the souls of anything living it touches.
The sword of swords, created by the Skaven to destroy the greatest Necromancer to ever walk the world. It is a doomed thing.
This weapon is inlaid with a thousand tiny barbed teeth, that still require feeding!
A legendary blade forged by Aren, one of the first Swordmasters of Hoeth. It is as tall as an Elf and as light as a willow switch.
Quenched in the poison of a thousand malicious serpents; when it strikes, poison flows into the veins of its victims.
This weapon is attached to a Warp-generator that channels crackling energy along its blade.
Warpstone powder mixed with steel during the forging process creates a weapon of wicked cutting prowess.
This weapon weeps a corrosive venom that can melt through armour to help deliver the poisoned point.
Whenever the God of the Savage Hunt's name is invoked blood shall flow, one way or another.
Battle Wizards are rarely armoured for it interferes with their casting, yet a steed can and should be barded to add a level of protection.
Imperial pegasi are found in Grey Mountains where Bretonnian and Empire hunters fight over capturing the foals.
Should a Battle Wizard need a mount, then his station would ensure he receives a warhorse of good breed.
The war boar is a stubborn and vicious animal - an extremely tough beast that is notoriously bad tempered, loudly flatulent, unpredictable, and wholly dangerous.
This enormous, revolting Arachnarok Spider shrine upon which the Shaman is borne forces even the branches of nearby trees to twist in revulsion at its diabolical passing.
The bond between rider and steed goes beyond friendship or family; they act as one.
Fly on your wings, like an eagle. Touch the sun. Track the foe, ambush, and defeat.
With its magnificent frame and the great plumes of steam of its snorting breath, the Great Stag instils unflinching valour into those who ride it.
No creature outmatches the Black Dragon Bracchus in terms of sheer cruelty and the ability to inflict pain, save for Rakarth himself!
Dark Elves hold no creature in higher esteem than the Manticore, for they believe it to be one of the thousand incarnations of Khaine.
Dark Elf Beastmasters roam the wilds atop their dreaded chariots, armed with barbed nets and harpoons to slay the foe and ensnare their prey.
This staff, imbued with the darkest of Dark Magics, enhances the magical abilities of its bearer on and off the battlefield.
This dark crucible is a powerful artefact that can harness and store a great reservoir of unstable magical energy.
Once the scourge of the Empire, Zhrakk's armour was found empty after his demise, but for the overpowering stench of brimstone.
This suit of armour runs red with thick strings of blood, sapping the strength of all Khorne’s enemies.
Such a symbol insults Order and all its supporters, to the delight of Destruction and Ruin.
Ever since the Daemon Prince Locephax angered the Gorequeen, his horned head and hypnotic eyes have adorned her shield.
Doooooooooooom! Let there be no misunderstanding…
To one blessed by Grandfather Nurgle, these elixirs are restorative brews, but to others they are debilitating poisons.
Some whisper that the gemstone is a crystalised tear of Slaanesh, able to slow all who behold it in awe.
Such armour is materialised from the dark energies of Chaos, guarding against the onslaught of Order.
Chaos is without end. Nothing can stop the eternal march of its forces, for its greatest warriors will always rise once more.
This putrid, rotting standard constantly seeps with a horrendous gruel of pus and mucus, helping to deflect incoming attacks from range.
The dread carriages of the Ruinous hosts are more than just machines of war; they are symbols of status and power.
The dread steeds of Chaos are more than mere horses, but creatures tainted by Daemon blood, said to be gifts from the Dark Gods themselves.
A massive construction of hell-forged metal, mutant beast and jagged blade, ridden to war only by the bloodthirsty.

An enchanted blade instils a certain magical 'wallop' to its bearer's attacks.
Fashioned by Slaanesh himself, Azazel's devilish sword strikes with a hellish force that even enchanted armour simply cannot deflect.
All the foe feels is a light tickling, as if touched by a feather. The reality, however, is that they've been brutally slashed to death.
Far more than a mere blade, the Sword of Change can also summon Chaos Spawn to the field, so that the Changer's insidious will may be realised upon the mortal plane.
The Gorequeen’s barbed spear has slain kings and paupers alike, ripping out hearts and striking heads from bodies with deft blows.
Forged by the Master Runesmiths of Slayers Keep, this rune forces back the corruption of the Undead and other Forces of Destruction.
The souls of this deadly dagger's victims are trapped within its onyx blade, where they must remain, subject to its wielder's magical whims.
Filled with boiling blood and cinder ash, this gem-encrusted chalice contains a powerful curse which can be unleashed to destabilise the Winds of Magic across the battlefield.

Forged from meteoric iron and blighted gold, quenched in innocent blood and bound with slain, hell-bound souls, the Crucible is said to have been the handiwork of the ancient Chaos Dwarf Sorcerer Azgorh himself.
This orb increases the Winds of Magic reserves available to the Sorcerer, enabling him to heal himself with power drawn from enemy magic-users.
This Dark Magic-imbued staff focuses the Sorcerer’s twisted mind, allowing them to act with supernatural haste.
The infamous castellan-commander of the Tower of Gorgoth was a general without peer, whose armour was so fashioned as to shield him from his rivals.
Though the Black Dwarfs forge the very best armour, such things are not necessary if you know the correct enchantments.
Dawi-Zharr armour is forged not simply from iron and fire, but blood, souls and the hell-stuff of Chaos itself. As such, it protects its wearer from the strongest blows, as well as fire and heat.
The sheer quality of this fine armour makes it able to withstand blows of any power, regardless of who is making them.
Few Dawi dare to imagine what horrors the exile Skavor crafted with his restless hands while donning these very braces, and only the insane claim to know…
Grungni's flaming helm enabled him to see his way when tunnelling the Dawi to safety, so they could regroup and face the Ruinous stranglehold gripping the world.
Some unfortunate Hobgoblin is probably being disembowelled for letting this out of his sight, even as we speak…
Believe it or not, it is possible to make furious Daemons even more, er, furious. This banner, inscribed with the symbols of Chaos and imbued with the darkest of sorceries, ought to do the trick!
This should ensure that the mercenary contingent keep to their part of the battlefield and not get *too* out of order.
The disdain the Chaos Dwarfs feel for their adversaries, weaponised so attacks against this mortal servant of Hashut can be further resisted.
They who stand behind this Chaos Dwarf symbol find their defensive capabilities improved and their will to fight on unshakeable, even in the face of likely defeat and destruction.
It's only right and proper that one should get some sort of reward for avoiding the Ogres' cook-pot!
The one thing the Vampire Counts have in abundance is spent corpses and skeletons, which can be acquired as souvenirs by the Dawi-Zharr Convoy riders.
This servant will never perish and will always do as commanded.
This beautifully-wrought shield will be most useful on the battlefield... Just don't stare too long into its highly-burnished surface, lest you become too enamoured of your own beard!
This shard of unmeltable ice is a symbol of the Norscan tribes, and their boundless loyalty to the Ruinous Ones…
One moment, it's a fine sword made from steel folded thousands of times; the next, it's a pen, for signing away one's soul… or sanity!
This be-tentacled… thing will surely come in handy at some point. Maybe for terrifying the labourers into some harder graft?
We didn't mean to bring him with us. No idea what use he will be, though. Perhaps the labourers will be inspired by all that waving and muttering?
Sometimes, extra protection is needed on the perilous journey back to the Plain of Zharrduk.
Watch out for this one and, whatever you do, don't put your hand on the end!
Oo! Ow! Ouch! Whose idea was this? Wazzock!
This powerful whip pierces through even the toughest armour and ensures everyone listens to you.
Those under its influence have no choice but to acknowledge their subjugation to their dark masters and take heart in the promise of their inevitable victory.
The runic carvings on this enchanted shield appear to writhe and twist when observed closely, and hold the power to destroy any enemy magicks ranged against it.
What dark forces will be released when this vessel is smashed? Believe me, you really don't want to find out!
Imagine the foe's (albeit brief) surprise when the heat of a thousand molten furnaces blasts forth and melts them to the spot.
These armoured gloves increase both the strength and stamina of their wearer, meaning they can stay in the fray far longer, and fight far harder, than would otherwise be possible.
The revered tools of the first Dwarf Engineer grant the holder the means to replicate Morgrim's innovation and crafting techniques for machineries of war.
Valaya's healing salve is a protective rune first used to shield the Dawi from the hostile magic to which they were exposed during the Ruinous Powers' incursions into reality.
Bound within this brazen, Daemon-faced mask is the essence and agonies of all those who have perished before its snarling visage in the forge-fires of sacrifice.
Within this ampoule is contained the "Blood of Hashut"; though highly unlikely to be true, it is nevertheless a powerful alchemical substance that ignites metal on contact.
One thing is certain in this terrible, terrible world: weapons of all shapes and sizes will always be needed.
If you can't buy it in cheaply, make it yourself. What you don't need can be sold – at a substantial profit, of course.
This captain of the Infernal Guard is especially cruel, being obsessed with drilling his recruits until they are exhausted, and sometimes even death for those not up to the job.
Someone to make sure captives stay in line and cannot escape to freedom.
The secrets of the God of Fire, Greed and Tyranny are revealed only to his most faithful servants, who, in turn, interprets them for mass consumption.
The most devoted acolytes of the Father of Darkness know best how to spread his word, and his will, to those under his thrall.
Believe it or not, Greenskins have a use besides yelling and throwing dung around.
The leaders of the Infernal Guard are clearly identifiable from their lavishly-decorated suits of armour …and the deafening roar of their voices when giving orders.
There are always improvements that can be made to any process; this one ensures the Chaos Dwarfs' war machines and artillery are adjusted and tweaked to perfection.
This one ensures the Infernal Legion marches to a set rhythm and cadence on its way to the massacre.
The Chaos Dwarfs' "dark tongue" requires special handling if the Daemon trapped inside its armoured carapace is to be bound there, and to their controlling Daemonsmith's will.
The Eastern Steppe tribes produce Hobgoblins of rather better quality than the usual dung-flinging, shouty rabble, some of whom can even be trusted with clandestine operations.
This experienced scout is immune to the privations of the deep desert, and can pass on his expertise to others of his ilk.
Knowing exactly where to strike, under which conditions, and when, is essential if you wish to launch successful ambushes in the desert.
When the Dawi-Zharr take to the waves, this one ensures that the fleet remains on course and reaches its destination.
This adept provides the necessary sigils and incantations to keep the Winds of Magic flowing and in the Daemonsmith's favour.
The Guardian passes on his extensive combat experience to the less experienced Bull Centaurs.
It's a dirty job, with terrible conditions and worse pay, but someone has to do it.
Labourers may well cease their labour if left unwatched, and knowing how hard you can beat a Greenskin without killing it outright is clearly really important!
Having someone on staff who knows the science behind everything, can craft useful things, and has a talent for organised production, is essential, because war is an industry.
No portraits of the influential Lahmian Sister exist, for she changes her appearance frequently and drains the blood of any aspiring artists who attempt to capture her likeness.
Wreathed in smoke, these huge, winged Daemonic-bulls are blessed with flesh that burns with the intensity of a living furnace that sparks the ground 'neath their hooves.
As creatures of flame and ash, the Red Bulls of Hashut cannot stray far from the Dark Lands, save for when the Winds of Magic – and Aqshy specifically – are at their strongest.
Believed to be a rare mutation of the Great Taurus, the magical Lammasu are the living embodiment of the Dark Land's rage, exhaling sorcerous clouds to protect their riders.

The finest horses in the Old World, bred for their endurance and fiery temperament, barded for further protection.
A double-edged sword, so to speak, for although this jewel protects its owner from attack, they cannot attack anyone while wearing it either.
The icy hate of Drazhoath's malice is amplified a thousandfold within its black crystal depths, and unleashed on any who would dare spill his blood.
Upon this tablet are faded runes etched by Thungni himself after he resurfaced from the Glittering Realm where he discovered the secrets of Rune Magic.
Shaving his head and exposing his tattooed flesh to the world, Grimnir journeyed north to face Chaos armoured only with a few trinkets of gold.
For some, hatred softens and eventually passes with the passage of time. Not so the Chaos Dwarfs, whose seething rancour, once felt, will last forever and a day at the very least.
The bearer of this charm finds themselves possessed by a long-dead servant of Ruin, whose warrior prowess flows through their veins to strike at the foe with even greater violence.
Created from the flayed, greying flesh of apprentice Sorcerers who failed Astragoth, the Mantle both preserves Ironhand's chosen and reminds them of the price of failure.
Weapons suffused with arcane strength will fall quiet when near to this blacker-than-black periapt.
This black-shafted hammer bears the horned rune of Hashut, Father of Darkness, and has been carried into battle for centuries by the champions of Zharr-Naggrund.
This blade whispers thoughts of murder and violence to any that grasp its hilt, and remains gleaming, no matter how much bloody work it has done.
This fearsome tempered axe can split apart armour with great ease, rendering even the most well-forged plate useless.
This nasty spiked club smoulders with a dark power that seems to eat the light around it and devours its victims' body heat, leaving them nought but withered husks.
Neither armour nor wards can turn Ulrika's silver blade from its target, such are its innate magical properties.
Within his white-hot brazier, the Lord of Underearth uncovered the signature runes that granted his fellow Ancestor Gods the power to control elemental forces.
Smednir was the first of the Ancestor Gods to craft the crushing rune-weapons – such as this ornately-carved hammer – for which the Dawi are rightly infamous.
One blow from this Darkforged sword is equivalent to several from an ordinary, unenchanted blade.
A badge of rank and high office, this iron staff-mace, which carries the runic names of every past master of the Black Fortress, is bound with baleful prayers to Hashut.
Research notes from Cathay, detailing various methods for creating and disrupting magical wards. It would be fitting to put it to use against its creator…
You found this horn while fighting Black Arks in Naggaroth. Whilst you have since moved on, the dead are not quick to forget: blowing it can temporarily bring them back to your side.
The power of Dragons, captured in battle and twisted for your devious schemes. The Daemons of Tzeentch can put it to much better use…
Centred within the Mother’s circlet of claws, an ancient artefact suspended in ever-frozen ice strengthens her kinship with the sentinel-spirits of the land.

Those masters of the hidden lore of Ghur speak of bloody rites to be performed before a great idol of beast skulls and freshly flensed hides should one dare to call upon the power of the Bloody Hidesman, and the terrible price of doing so.
These cracked and jumbled scrolls contain details of every spell ever written – though finding the correct one at the opportune moment can be something of a challenge.
Some say the Changeling’s stave is the source of his power. Wiser heads assume that is a lie and merely a prop of the Prankster’s manipulations. Perhaps it is both… or neither?
Through the many jade eyes adorning Yuan Bo’s armour, the Moon Empress can see all and exert her will through his regentship.
Given to him by the Moon Empress, legend has it this imposing headdress allows Ming to control the Iron Winds.
A rudimentary set of armour, cobbled together from forgotten experiments discarded in the darkest corners of Hell Pit. Don't worry about the dried up mutagenic gunk, it's probably fine.
A gift from her father, the Coronal is said to be a locus, allowing Miao to wield the Storm Winds with ease.
The armour of an unknown mortal, acquired through your alliance with Kairos Fateweaver. Something about it seems awfully familiar to you...
While a man lacks the terrifying claws and jaws of a Manticore, he is just as capable of running you through with a blade.
You must be as swift as a coursing river...
No foolish thoughts of piercing the heart – aim for the meaty tissue at the joints!
Simmering with powerful arcane brews, the hag's curses and incantations take shape to summon forth the spirit-magic of the land.
One of the Tzeentch’s most mysterious and bizarre gifts, Aekold's body springs new and vigorous growth, constantly restoring his own lifeforce.
As a capable smith, these vambraces are thought to be Zhao’s own creations, allowing him to channel the power of Yang.
Created by artisans of Nan-Gau and imbued with dark Yin magic, they grant the Dragon Emperor’s daughter formidable arcane protection.
A divining rod can be used to seek out lost artefacts of the Old Ones or to investigate disturbances felt in the geomantic web.
Rare and majestic, Jade Longma only allow themselves to be ridden by the truly worthy.
A general's horse can be their most trusted and daring companion. Just don't name him 'Daisy'.
To bring fear and panic to a battlefield, few other than the Ice Court’s most accomplished can wrangle a deadly ice drake into their service.

The Ice Court’s reinforced sled is drawn by mighty steeds with breath like the winter wind, and whose flanks shimmer with glittering ice crystals.
From the Golden Knight’s resplendent armour hang trinkets bestowed by the High Patriarch, granting legitimacy in the eyes of both the Church and the State.
A small talisman you picked up in Ulthuan, now corrupted by the Ruinous Powers. Some magic still lingers, allowing your forces to recover faster after a battle.
Leftover Dwarfen beard-fluff from your encounters with Grombrindal. Many in your army think it is from the White Dwarf himself. It's probably best to not correct them…
Having acquired the form of Astragoth Ironhand, you've been able to sneak into Zharr-Naggrund to pilfer a bit of the Chaos Dwarfs' fabled firepower.

There's supposedly some kind of colossal sea creature patrolling the waters around Galleon's Graveyard. This is, apparently, a tusk from that likely fictional creature. Whatever the origin, it has some uses still.
This small orb seems to find its way back to its owner, no matter what they do with it. It does at least provide some spellcasting benefits.
An archaic bit of equipment you picked up, after your encounters with the forces of Lord Mazdamundi. It's inelegant, but has its uses.
This relic from Athel Loren has been enchanted with magical energies. Though its original purpose has been long since lost, you can probably draw power from its residual charge.
A tome from an unknown Necromancer, something to do with… Nagash. It's not much use to you, but it does give pointers on how to best fight them.
You found this runefang within the chaos of the erupting civil war you started within the Empire. At least it's probably a runefang... maybe.
Exquisitely crafted from one of the Celestial Dragon’s own teeth is the weapon of his executioner, wielded by the Jade Dragon with strength and authority.
Aekold’s excellent swordsmanship allows him to control this erratic and unpredictable double-handed Tzeentchian broadsword, hurling it at his enemies with devastating results.
A blade of unknown origin with which you absconded during your dealings with the assassins of Clan Eshin. They think they are the most devious schemers... They are wrong.
Used by Imperial mages, the wand aids spellcasting by increasing the chances of its success.
Friedrich von Tarnus was a seasoned warrior long before he became Magister Patriarch of the Bright Order. Even then, his magical talent was clear for all to see.
Anraheir made this cloak from the toughened hide of a Minotaur; it strikes fear into the heart of every beast that beholds it.
Prototype Field Coat Mark XXIV is the future of projectile-proof battle wear. Unlike Mark XXIII, this version doesn’t catch fire when struck!
Balthazar Gelt's vestments are woven with protections following the notable incident in which he almost blew himself up during an alchemical experiment gone badly wrong.
To have defeated, and then decapitated, such a colossal, and deadly predator as an Arachnarok Spider is the sign of a warrior of significant prowess, and growing legend.
Dragonhide cloaks are worn more for the prestige of being thought a Dragon-killer than for any protection they offer.
The Doomfire Ring, made from dark iron and flame rubies, contains a powerful spell that allows its bearer to cast fire upon their enemies.
This enchanted root from Athel Loren gifts the power of healing to whomsoever is holding it.
When brought into contact with this jewel, weapons ignite with ice-cold blue flames that burn anything they touch.
First designed to aid Dwarfs working white-hot forges, this rune has been adapted for use in battle.
This enchanted talisman constantly bends light around the bearer, causing incoming projectiles to follow the streams of Hysh back to assailants.
As the sands of time slip through the hourglass, decay embraces all, reminding us of the eternal cycle of life and death, and the omnipresent touch of Nurgle's rot.
In the deepest, darkest forests stand enormous, ancient trees that've grown ever more malignant as the centuries have flown by. Their evil bark offers protection from attack.
With a tip crafted from meteoric iron and engraved with the runes of the heavens, this lance strikes its target like a bolt of lightning, both burning and blasting the foe to ash.
When enemies think they are safe at range, wise Grungni ensures their confidence is misplaced.
...by which all other warriors shall be measured, further warded for invulnerability.
Crafted by the Foetid Brewmaster, Ku'gath Plaguefather, this vellum pouch absorbs all known curses and poisons.
The dread carriages of the Ruinous hosts are more than just machines of war; they are symbols of status and power.
The dread steeds of Chaos are more than mere horses, but creatures tainted by Daemon blood, said to be gifts from the Dark Gods themselves.
This vile, mutilated steed bears its rider into the very thick of battle, where any wounds scored upon its cancerous flesh are sealed by the pus weeping from its foetid body.
The dread steeds of Chaos are more than mere horses, but creatures tainted by Daemon blood, said to be gifts from the Dark Gods themselves.
A vast, mobile altar allows the souls of the slain to be ritualistically condemned directly from the field of slaughter.

A vast, mobile altar allows the souls of the slain to be ritualistically condemned directly from the field of slaughter.
Battle Wizards are rarely armoured for it interferes with their casting, yet a steed can and should be barded to add a level of protection.
Imperial pegasi are found in Grey Mountains where Bretonnian and Empire hunters fight over capturing the foals.
The rune of the Ancestor God of Runesmiths hardens both the axe and armour of the Dwarf who bears it.
This tool is a powerful yet confusing artefact; it allows the user to read the heavens for ill omens, yet it always relates to what tomorrow's stars will say.
Gifted to Bruckner by Elspeth von Draken, to protect him from the foul sorceries of the Maggot Lord, this black gem possesses powers unknown, and served Elspeth's own deadly schemes.
A ruby-red jewel imbued with a swirling energy; attaching it to a weapon grants it strange powers…
To each of his Chieftains Tamurkhan granted a powerful talisman, to enhance their power, but also to yoke it to his own through Nurgle's immense will.
You put enough lenses in a scope and you can probably even see the surface of the Twin-Tailed Comet itself!
When the sands of death run down, nothing in existence – or not – can hold back the deadly Winds of Shyish.
The finest blades forged within the Slayer's Keep, designed to bring down the largest and most ferocious monsters on the battlefields of the Old World.
Sometimes the pen is mightier than the sword, but in the case of the Tallyman, the two are equally dangerous.
That which is not taboo of Chaos Dwarf weapon manufacturing can be learned from, resulting in a Dawi-made weapon far superior in every way.
For centuries this long blade has been used by the city of Nuln's champion in preference to the more traditional headsman's axe.
A sickle made purely from oak, but just as hard as the hardest metal. Its wielder has a strong affinity with the Winds of Ghyran and can channel that energy into healing those around them.
The meagre runts ignominiously cleaved in two will never know the defilement brought on by the debilitating wave of Nurgle's will... which may be a mercy to most!
Gifted to him by the Chaos Dwarfs of the Black Mountains, the greyish fumes produced when this weapon is swung are foully poisonous... which pleases the Maggot Lord greatly!
This ancient, storied sword is rumoured to be the first one ever forged. It certainly seems to have an uncanny power over other weapons...
The flame burning at the end of this enchanted staff matches the anger levels of its bearer.
Forged through transmutation, no mortal-forged metal can withstand its devastating slice; the foe's armour is cut to pieces like so much ribbon at its touch.
Atop Gnarla, his War Boar of prodigious size, might and flatulence, Gorbad has bellowed many a thunderous call to a successful Waaagh!
The Blood God’s own Flesh Hound is a colossal Daemon of great power, ridden on the battlefield in the fashion of a monstrous beast.
A vast, mobile altar allows the souls of the slain to be ritualistically condemned directly from the field of slaughter.
Skulltaker’s is the most dreaded Juggernaut of all, a metal-plated beast of primordial rage that carries the Slayer of Kings to his doomed quarries.
The owner of the living head was decidedly unlucky; the previous owner of the shrunken head, likewise. Surely, the current owner would be the lucky one!
Been 'avin strange dreams lately... Wearin' a tin on me head an' ridin' a Gnoblar...
The mighty former breastplate of a many-named, widely-famed Tomb Warrior, and the current gutplate of a big-named, well-fed Ogre.
Presently worn by the most brutally cunning Ogre in his tribe.
I reckon I can make a new armguard from this 'ere tin...
Dat me gut talkin' or me new gutplate? Stop ya conversatin', both of ya!
A loincloth to withstand the hardest and most underhanded of blows.
A miraculous gutplate that, along with protecting its owner it battle, cures the worst cases of indigestion.
The mind-dulling effects of this otherwise awe-inspiring attire, when worn by an Ogre, are all but negligible on its owner.
An Ogre would never be caught wearing a full suit of armour. Thankfully, the Nightshroud merely manifests around him. At worst, it makes others bump into him. Worst for them, that is.
Strapped to an Ogre's wrist, a shield of this size would be little more than an adornment. Yet somehow, it deflects both blows and missile fire with ease.
It is meant to sharpen the mind and the senses of those who wear it on their heads. It still confers some of its effects when used as a bowl.
Oi, 's got some scratches on't but it fits!
Berserk rage manifests differently in different creatures. Some Maneaters have learned to keep their hunger unsated and release the pent-up fury all at once in battle.
The Dark Elf practice of consuming Black Dragon Eggs speaks to the heart and soul of what it is to be an Ogre: adventurous, opportunistic eating, and consequences be damned.
Widely-travelled Maneaters have developed a taste for pre-smoked meat – black powder efficiently initiates the smoking process while terminating its 'living process'!
Don' throw it in tha fire! Don' eat it! Ya know... Jus' give it t'me.
Through cunning use of diplomacy, the Maneaters have acquired a piece of advanced technology from the Chaos Dwarfs for the price of just a few dented skulls (not their own).
While unerring devotion is usually the prerequisite for such an honour, unusually effective service is also rewarded – and the Maneaters' services are as effective as they are unusual.
The Unliving can afford a few mistakes when throwing explosives. The Maneaters just chuck them as far as they can and pray they remembered to light the fuse!
Ogres don't put much stock in the spiritual side of eating their foes, but sometimes that spiritual side creeps in after the eating is done.
A silent glare from an Ogre is as unlikely as bare-chested bloodlust from a Vampire. But when it happens, it is the silence itself that becomes glaring, stunning foes into terror.
If you are strong enough that nothing can stop your advance, what stops you from making it so you halt *any* advance?
Living 'ard? Hah!... What do they know?...
Vampiric blessings often carry sinister overtones, but what is more sinister yet is when such blessings are bestowed upon an Ogre.
Useful both in the heat of battle and when some drunken Ogre throws an oversized bone at your back.
They said they wave it at 'orses so them beasts know when t'go. Some of our boys could use that.
Kislevites sing of such charges as they mourn their dead. Ogres tell tales of the same as they enjoy their food – which may or may not be the Kislevites.
The Wood Elves' fierce, overbearing pride in the Wildwood has found fertile soil in the Ogres' overbearing certainty that it holds no threat bigger than them.
The truly hawk-eyed never miss. And neither do the truly ham-handed.
The significance of hell-forging requires an understanding the numerous finer points of swordmaking, but who needs a fine point when your entire blade is ablaze?
One does not need to know what a banner symbolises to draw strength from it, especially a Skaven one. It is as potent as it is indecipherable.
Made from the pelt of a beast that was impossible to kill with arrows, the numerous holes in it notwithstanding. However, still makes a good tale during Maneater feasts.
I seen 'em feathered tinnies scream an' charge like they were one o'us! Honest! Makes me like'em more, though I never had a taste for them.
The first step in teaching Ogres to stalk their prey is to tell them, repeatedly, not to move  or do anything. Only certain Maneaters know what the other steps are.
Ogres have overcome enough challenges outside of battle alone to make even High Elves raise an eyebrow. Some Ogres realise what such strength means during battle.
When Dark Elves speak of slaughter, the word belies their finely-honed killing techniques. To Ogres, the word will forever be as literal as rock.
Hidin' and killin' em with poison?! Huh. Does it make 'em taste better with poison in 'em?
A mark of honour seemingly tailor-made to Ogres, especially when they recognise its potential as a weapon.
Too troublesome when stuck in one's teeth, and hardly a worthy meal. Besides, their hidden martial capabilities make these birds worthy pets.
The notion of a predator carries a somewhat overblown connotation of pride. The reality of a predator is... well, an Ogre. A rose by any other name, and all that…
Ogre Mercenaries borrow various foreign affectations in garb, weaponry and even speech. However, the Lizardmen have reminded them of the unchanging, naked, wordless monster beneath.
Magnanimous' Ogres are no such thing by any other measure but their own. To be a short-tempred one is to make even rough Norscans flinch.
Surprise! is what an Ogre shouts when charging from a battlefield away. Imagine anyone's surprise then, when it happens from much, much closer.
All the cleverness and lethality of a Red Crest Skink with but a fraction of the fidgeting and screeches that make them so hard to skin and boil properly.
The Ogres' indiscriminate appetites have made them both the towering threat that they are, and with some helping of Undead meat, an outright explosive menace.
Easy and straightforward to etch or splash onto anything, and as reliable as anything the Dwarfs provide.
What makes it so distracting? The hodge-podge of tatters on it? The half-scrawled nonsense? ...Oh, is that a butterfly over there?
Some Ogres do not realise how inherently suicidal their way of life really is, or do not care. Swearing a Slayer Oath amends their ignorance, but otherwise changes nothing.
There is no taunt that an Ogre does not already embody. They have simply learned to address all their points of pride to their enemies. Why does it make them so angry?
The Vampires' Hunger makes them thirst endlessly, even in the middle of battle. For Ogres, Hunger is hunger. Tear a foe's leg, kill another with it, eat the leg.
Killing Daemons is so difficult that some humans have dedicated their lives to it. For Ogres, it is just a *little* harder than usual, but now they also have a reason to do it.
So... I won't die if I'm stubborn enough? Mebbe thass why I'm still alive!
A potent portent of doom, as if it being waved about as an Ogre banner was not enough of a clue.
Truly a warcry for all time.
Uniquely styled to appeal to Ogres – namely, thick enough to act as a second skin. The colours are mostly primary, but its status as art has always been secondary, anyway.
Er, is it made for witches, or *from* witches?... Eitha way...
An Ogre's worthy foe is one that has the most meat on it. Coincidentally, they are also the most difficult to kill – a fortunate coincidence in philosophies.
That white bit on it means our guts are strong like the Mountains o' Mourn!
That black bit on it means our shots are strong like the Fire Mouth!
Those Cathay quacks like their iron so much, they even drinks it!
A miraculous map that, when followed by Ogres, always leads to a battle instead of treasure. They do not mind either way!
Those Cathay quacks like their stars so much, they bottled 'em!
Puzzled by Dwarfen paroxysms of rage at the very sight of it, Ogres finally decided that stunties disapprove of wearing beards backwards. A justified reaction, if a little extreme.
Keeps sand out of me mouth? Good. I'd ratha eat somethin' meatier.
Somethin' shouting inside... 'S like a little man boilin' in a pot. Hahahaha!
A sip contains the strength of many men, or in this case, the strength of a foul-tempered Ogre with a roaring hangover.
Hey, if dat mouldy pile'o'bones in there is still mean an' kickin', I can do it too!
Foun' some canned meat talkin to this 'ere piece of wood. Hey! Piece-o'-wood lady! Say somefin'!
Killed some git that killed a Mannikor... Reckon this makes me the Mannikor-killer-killer!
Dis some kin' of fire poker?
Putting this on makes it very difficult to take off. Ogres have found that the resulting arm-flailing, however, lends itself well to a powerful, if curious, combat technique.
Barging headfirst into a maelstrom of magick while wearing a feathered cloak and screaming is a ploy as simple and as successful as most Ogres' battle tactics.
Oi! Sounds like somethin' roarin' in there like it missed a meal or two!
As digusting as it is, Ogres think it's still better than the meat, and given their usually indiscriminate palate, that says a lot.
It takes dexterity not to turn such a weapon on yourself by accident. Ogres are willing to take that risk... or they don't know of it!
A thin stick and a string, or else a net, and patience: all things alien to Ogres, but they enjoy the fish well enough.
A master of the skillset an Ogre best appreciates: being angry and being violent. So very, *very* violent.
An implausible marriage of a halfling's prodigious capacity for cooking and an Ogre's capacity for consuming food… including any cook who fails to meet their demand.
A merchant he may be, but there's not much trade taking place. He simply points his masters in the direction of weapons and they take them from their previous owners.
Dis new chef seems ta be able to just cook forever!
He knows better than to hawk his wares to Ogres. Still, a living, breathing, well-dressed human in their company is bound to improve others' opinion of their horde.
A servant of Slaanesh would certainly appreciate the pleasure of a good meal. Watching Ogres enjoy one makes one reconsider that tenet of one's faith, however.
Elves are a race of contrasts: their lords are glorious and terrible, their slaves are garrulous and tiresome. Or as Ogres call them, a meal in the making.
The ingredients he is forced to use are highly unconventional, but various forms of fermented... stuff can be found plentifully from which a drink could be made.
Incredibly, almost as skilled as a Bruiser in putting an end to internal tribal conflict. His only challenge is ensuring Tyrants remain appreciative.
In the eyes of Ogres, a Gnoblar in disguise, or maybe a couple, stacked on top of each other and wearing a patchwork overcoat.
When you choose the life of an entertainer, you rarely consider the possibility of plying your trade for the sake of your life.
Ogre captives do not entertain the notion of release for ransom. However, they do provide entertainment for their captors, courtesy of a well-maintained fighting pit.
Oi, gemme somethin' to eat! No, no Squigs aroun' ya daft runt! But bring me one o' those, too, if you see it.
As the Gnoblar is beneath the Goblin, the Snotling is beneath a Gnoblar. Ogres, in their turn, often don't even know what these creatures even are.
Never has a food-taster been more disgusted and afraid to eat something that is not poison. Usually.
Ogres only pay attention to his songs if he stops singing. It is not the kind of audience reaction that bodes well when there's piping-hot cauldron and campfire around.
If no Mammoths, Stonehorns or Thundertusks are around, tame Ogres are the ones that maybe *don't* eat you, right?
Those serving the will of the Maw are well-served by one dedicated to serving maws. In truth, they are mostly under-served. It is a bonding experience.
Bigger, stronger and more willing than Gnoblars, some also willingly go into the pot if they consider their term served, as a form of release.
A proud contributor to recent Ogre breakthroughs in agriculture.
I push 'im in the pot, 'e climbs back out! 'S unnatural, 's what it is!
Always on the lookout for drapes to dust, but his search has hithertho been futile. As a piece of internal decoration or even couture, Ogres are notably disinclined towards drapery.
Though well-suited to the sort of exotic weaponry most Ogres can barely use, should he sermonise about weapon design, this one is swiftly met with its apex: a large club.
He has not yet been eaten, miraculously. If anything, his numerous escapes and retrievals have started to teach Ogres something about subtlety in hunting.
Firebellies have tried to eat it. Barely have they swallowed when it finds its way out again... violently!
Yheetees bask in the icy blast like old women around a hearth. Other Ogres may complain about their campfires going out, but they know better than to challenge Yheetees on such grounds.
To Ogres, it's just blood-soaked dirt, but as they have taken to fashioning their own versions of it, it seems to help with improving discipline.
Ogres would prefer pendants with more heft to them, but that rat skull definitel seems to grow heavier in the presence of magick... Must be something to it…
Ogres have heard it said that they should not eat this under any circumstances, but have not made up their minds as of yet.
Tells me to kill people. Like I don' know! Shut up already! I'll kill 'em, ya'll see! AAAARGH!
Definitely not Bugman's. If anything, it induces something beyond sobriety. Surprised as they are by how well it makes them fight, Ogres hate it.
Huh... Now thassa differen't kind of eatin'. More!
At first, it caused a campside fight: when an Ogre poked the tribal pot in impatience and pierced it through like cloth. From then on, the tribe appreciated the weapon in an entirely new light.
Multi-purpose: capable of piercing five men clean through and suitable for then mounting over a fire to cook them.
Though looking at it makes one's eyes water, it is supremely good at beating battlefield foes into shapes convenient for cooking.
Hook-hands are bad for an Ogre's digestion, unlike their owners, but they make for a good memento.
Thanks to this implement, Ogres have recently discovered the joys of punching holes through things in addition to smashing them, though none of these things are rocks.
It is not made to size for an Ogre, but its usage is familiar enough. A spiked gauntlet swung forcefully enough will make enough contact for the tiny poisoned blade to do its job.
For creatures as wasteful with their force as Ogres, this extremely efficient weapon guarantees that even if they mostly miss, a simple graze can spell death for the foe.
Ogres bearin this axe are generally oblivious to the fact that it was made to serve those who seek death in battle. They only know it is *extremely* good at killing.
Some magical weapons whisper mysteriously, some scream in eldritch rage, and some just buzz – warning of foes with exactly the level of vocabulary an Ogre appreciates.
Found some tinned food preying at the lake, got myself a new sword and a good snack!
This weapon will never break as long as its bearer is on a worthy quest. Apparently, the Ogre's life of a wandering warrior is sufficiently quest-like for the purpose.
In Elven hands, such a bow hones an archer's already fearsome proficiency. In an Ogre's mits, it essentially does all the work.
Not sure about dis sword takin' a bite outta ma meals before I can...
Slender enough to be used as a toothpick by an Ogre, poisonous enough to be used in such manner only once.
A sword producing fire from the very air is an inconvenient cooking technique, unless the meal meets the blade half-way. Ogres have made it work.
A Warpstone-forged weapon usually has dramatic effects on those in its proximity. Its Ogre bearers, for instance, experience mild indigestion. Their enemies experience irreversible death.
A gnawing sense of wrongness emanates from this stone, a constant when the Winds of Magic threaten to carry all away.
Famous for his loud voice and total contempt for all Gnoblars, Bannaga's invention causes a line of explosions to clear the foe from the bearer's path.
A skull-shaped chalice that promises salvation, or death...
A relic of the great Astromancer Po Mei, this enchanted cloak grants its wearer exceptional magical strength and mastery over one of the Elemental Winds.
A gift to Tsar Uriy from his wife, this exquisitely enamelled and bejewelled blown Frost Wyrm egg was the final and greatest masterwork of legendary jeweller Gastuva.
Grut the Bloodthirsty's culinary malevolence seems to live on in his rusty sickle, which gives the Butcher greater command over the Winds, but at a cost to his own health.
Rumoured once to have belonged to Skrag the Slaughterer, this book is the lone remnant of the Halfling Wars, used by Butchers when practicing the more unpalatable aspects of Gut Magic.
By forcing this ichor-soaked, Ruin-imbued heart of a foul Chaos Spawn down, the Butcher may create a vortex of magical anarchy that beguiles magic-using adversaries.
Amber is the colour of beasts. Such magic can ensnare and entrap animals much more easily than so-called "intelligent" species.
Spellcasters who practise Death Magic can channel the life force of foes into their spells.
Fire feeds fire, two blazes together are stronger and hotter than two apart.
Spells from the Lore of Heavens manipulate the ethers of the skies, buffeting and pummelling winged creatures.
Even the simplest of spells can bring forth the full bloom of renewal, reinvigorating and healing the broken and bleeding.
Light Magic excels at the scourging of the supernatural, be they Daemons and creatures of Chaos, or the unquiet dead.
Armour is little defence against a skilled alchemist, under his command metal turns into an arcane lightning rod, attracting hostile magic.
A conjured shadow is just as obfuscating as a real one - the Shadow Wizard is master or mistress of the 'concealing' arts.
When activated, this strange, extra-worldly artefact from the broken lands around the Great Maw greatly increases the power of friendly Wizards' spells.
A hand mirror fashioned from flawless ice, with an intricate frame of frostwork, will reflect the foe's violence back on himself.
This colourless crystal splits and intensifies light that falls upon it, twisting it into dazzling and unsettling hues that further empower the spellcaster in combat.
A big stick is a useful implement, especially when it can command the obedience of the enemy as well as your own troops.
This crystal shaft can transform a feeble wielder of magic into a brawny hero for a time, but with Tzeentch there is always a price to be paid...
These ancient relics chart the stars over Cathay for centuries to come and are able to help their users predict the future.
Ropes, wood, hair, iron nails and hide are twisted into a hideous ritual mask infused with the fears of the Ogres' defeated foes.
Apparently a simple pendant in the shape of a snowflake, it constantly changes its form, adopting a new and unique shape each time.
Kairos lives apart from the flow of time. Thus, he does not easily succumb to ill-fortune, for fate can easily be altered if one has the proper knowledge.
Created by the Jade Dragon Yuan Bo, this enchanted staff has the power to manipulate the Elemental Winds themselves, causing them to blow stronger or weaker on command.
When the pendulum swings, the foe's spellcasters find themselves powerless and magically impotent.
Krysothos is gone now, bound to a feathered grimoire, but his bones linger still and steal magic whenever they can – magic that their wielder can harness to his own ends.
A dissonant cry for battle emanates from this war gear, betokening an eerie anomaly in the sorcery that empowered it.
Clad in bale-forged armour laden with runes of slaughter and carnage, the Daemon's hide is all but immune to the blows of mortal men.
This suit of ancient scale carries with it the blessing of the Bear-God, allowing the wearer to shrug off blows that would fell an ox and fortifying their strength.
This harness' scales and plates have been wrought to the delicacy and gossamer weight of silk, yet are somehow the stronger for it.
The writhing thorns and brambles of this armour work their way into the bearer's surroundings, rendering them invisible to all but the most observant foe.
A heavy-duty gut-plate with two sharp curving horns jutting out, wrenched from the skull of a mighty cave-beast. The ground itself shakes when the bearer makes a bull charge.
A solid hunk of wood between you and the enemy provides both protection and confidence.
This cloak scintillates with the colours of nearby leaves, making the wearer's location nearly impossible to discern.
Worn only by Kislev's greatest warriors, this embossed plate harness is inset with frost shards harder and more pure than diamonds.
With no obvious joints this armour makes no apparent sense, but when did the powers of Chaos care for such details?
A mighty greatcloak fashioned from the pelt of a gigantic bear, the fur so thick as to be almost impenetrable.
This ancient, tattooed cave-beast skull, worn as a gut-plate, bleeds hostility and confusion into the minds of any who would do its bearer magical harm.
This polished brass gut-plate has a set of huge silver jaws attached to it that swallow the bearer's kills and pass them straight into the Great Maw. Their lifeforce passed to the wearer in return.
To those who don the Helm of Draesca comes untold power, yet a sorry fate also awaits…
Fashioned from scales of super-dense ice hewn from a glacial core and fashioned into a suit of black mail from which emanates a numbing cold.
Blows struck against its infinitely fine ceramic layers dislodge the uppermost one, leaving the assailant off-balance and wide open for a counter-thrust.
A solid cap that hides a hidden compartment, it smells faintly of loamy Talabecland dirt.
Forged by the Chaos Dwarfs in exchange for hundreds of Human and Gnoblar slaves, this great set of plates and chainmail shifts and hardens in response to incoming attacks.
Blows aimed at this armour's wearer are not blocked by it. Somehow, they never even connect…
The baleful enchantments of this ebony armour rob all nearby magical artifacts of their power.
Its iridescent alloy plates flow fluidly over one another, lending power and grace to the wearer, yet hardening instantaneously at the point of contact.
Surprisingly lightweight considering its bulk, and somehow containing everything under the sun from which to fashion bolts, bullets, shells and more.
Laced with Warpstone dust, this robe's black silk is constantly in motion, as if worried by a ceaseless furnace wind, so it is often difficult to make out what is robe and what is wearer.
Fashioned from scales of the Celestial Dragon himself, this armour is worn only by the greatest Cathayan heroes, that they may resist blows and traverse terrain without impediment.
A shield polished to such a degree that it reflects almost anything, be it a weapon’s blow or the metaphysical force of an enemy spell.
Once borne by a great hero of the Motherland, such is the reverence in which this shield is held that men willingly lay down their lives to protect its bearer.

Light fails to reflect normally from this amulet, and when struck by magic it remains undamaged, even as the arcane energies dissipate.
Sometimes the greatest sensation can be derived from the denial of the same in another.
When you're trying to a hit an angry speck on the horizon, luck must take some small part.
This enchanted, basin-sized crown was forged by artisans of the Empire for a king's ransom in gold, and is said to increase Overtyrant's intellect to near-human levels.
In the presence of hostile magics, the mauve stone of this ring flashes and sends a delicious tingle to the wearer's very core.
Although once a finely-wrought gemstone bound into a silver filigree cone, it is now a dirt-encrusted, chipped remnant of its former glory, its defensive powers resisting powerful attacks.
Swung on tarnished chains, the ominous clouds belching from this obscene censer are of deadly fungal spores rather than smoke, clouding the stinging eyes of would-be assailants.
Smelted from a fallen star found on the snowy steppes, the metal of this ring is dark and cold.
Bestowed by Grandfather Nurgle to his favoured champions, this green-rimmed necklace of bronze is a promise of his protection.
What is unmaking but a shackle to bind a Daemon from following his rage?
Pulsing like a malign heart, its taproot questing for purchase, this disgusting object seeks to root itself in flesh.
Mirrors have the power to reflect and reverse. Mix in something of the Warp, and that which is reflected can encompass all manner of things.
This Wyrdstone shard has been bound into a crude necklace where it quietly and silently absorbs its bearer's lifeforce.
The final work of an ancient master-craftsman, this sword draws reverence from those lucky enough to see it even once. Its wielder is destined to be a legend who brings singing death in battle.
This enchanted bow transforms its arrows into live (and very unhappy) snakes. Take care to protect your arms!
This unholy blade screams with the power of the Daemon bound inside it – one eternally thirsty for the blood of mortals.
A bearded battle-axe with a blade wreathed in crackling lightning, befitting of Tor, God of Storms.
The merest touch of this massive befouled blade is fatal to all creatures, Daemon, mortal and Undead.
This weighty blade trembles with a portion of Khorne's boundless rage; its strike crushes not only flesh and armour, but the victim's very soul as well.
A shadow made manifest; a blade as cruel as its owner.
The hero Xen Wu is a controversial figure in the mythology of Grand Cathay. His exploits were legendary, but his methods were questionable.
The Bloodcleaver is a revolting, gore-encrusted hand weapon with the vampiric ability to channel the lifeforce from its victims into its wielder.
At the wielder's command, the teeth race down the blade, ripping apart armour and flesh as easily as if they were parchment. The beast-hilt howls while it does so and whines if left unsated.
One of two powerful Elven Runeswords, forged long ago with its sister sword {{tr:weapon_elthraician}}.
Apparently forged from a reflection of the dawning sun, its blade is highly reflective, making the light dance and flash to the rhythm of its deadly pattern.
A mace with a fiery head, blazing with the light of Dazh, God of Fire. Its touch reinvigorates tired warriors in the thick of battle.
This handgun bears the mark of Aqshy on its barrel, and scorches the hands of the holder; its effectiveness, however, is undeniable.
One of two powerful Elven Runeswords, forged long ago with its sister sword {{tr:weapon_cynatcian}}.
This weapon flickers in and out of reality at the Daemon's merest command, allowing it to bypass a foe's defences and cut into the soft flesh beneath.
The runes upon this brazen axe still glow from the heat of its forging upon Khorne's anvil.
A single blow landed with this truly deadly magic sword is enough to fell even mighty beasts.
The frost shard blade of this revered weapon sparkles with the cold, hard promise of sharp slaughter.
This blade of Gilellion the Lewd, champion of Slaanesh, traps its victims in immortal servitude to its bearer.
Razor-edged and honed on souls who have fallen in battle to the Blood God's own, this blade is consecrated to Khorne and the bloody task of slaughtering his enemies.
The gnarled and twisted limbs of this bow do nothing to hamper its uncanny precision.
The Jade Blade is an ancient weapon fashioned from the fang of a Lumbrian sea monster. Imbued with the monsters regenerative powers, it continually heals its wielder.
The cords of this whip are spun from soul-stuff, hungry for escape. When the lash cracks forward, the soul-streamers splay outward, striking wildly at all nearby.
A more deadly strain of the plague-ridden Nurglings that burst from Ku'gath's body. These creatures are particularly scabrous, spreading a necrotic toxin to everything they touch.
The legendary hero Nuku Cho was a woman of few words. Her weapon had much to say, however, spitting flurries of furious bolts faster than thought.
The traditional weapon of Empire Outriders unleashes a devastating armour piercing volley, though the reloading leaves something to be desired!
This flail's heads are the shrunken skulls of plague victims, its chain crafted from knotted and desiccated entrails. Pestilence hangs heavy about it still, ever seeking to escape.
Balanced both to swing and to throw with equal bite.
This massive sceptre is ensorcelled with spells of might, imbuing Greasus with the strength of a Sky-Titan, as befits his status as the most powerful Ogre alive.
The metal of this blade is alloyed with a powerful venom; its merest touch is sufficient to lock a man's sinews rigid and stop his heart in the blink of an eye.
Its blade crafted from the Norscan glaciers and magically bound to remain forever frozen, when this mighty polearm strikes, the foe’s blood turns to ice.
A huge, two-handed obsidian club used by the Tyrant Bruto Thundergut to smash his way into the Skycastles thousands of years ago.
Every line and motion of this bow speaks to the grace of the Moon Empress who inspired its creation.
This blade of scales with a sharkskin hilt was borne from the deeps by a Norscan reaver in an age long past.
This heavy, spiked metal gauntlet was originally worn by Big Agi Skullplucker, who had a particular dislike for Elves and enjoyed nothing more than using it to twist off their girly little heads.
Less a string and more a knot of rope, enchanted using the Winds of Azyr. The bearer’s shots loose with staggering force to turn enemy shields.
The beatific sword of the Dark Prince, said to hold the sharpest edge in existence.
Each of these Daemonic axes contains a Bloodthirster's savage spirit, lending fury to Skarbrand's strikes.
This spear, able to pierce any armour, was made from the horn of the Great Spirit Qilin Tian Wu. Able to pierce any armour, heroes of Cathay carry it into battle with pride.
The mere presence of this staff causes all natural things to cry out in pain as it reshapes the world according to the Daemon's whim.
Within this rod is bound the essence of a particularly loathsome Plague Daemon, who chortles with horrible delight when his pox-ridden power is unleashed upon a deserving foe.
Bartered by a chieftain for his tribesmen's souls who then double-crossed the Dark Gods, this spear, that can banish their servants, is all that remains.
The Burning Brazier holds a flame taken from the Temple of Ursun. The more wounded the wielder becomes, the hotter the fire burns, and more terrible is its flaming touch.
Present at every major battle since the dawn of time, this blade guarantees its owner great worldly renown as long as it consents to their will.
This glittering sword has been wielded by some of Kislev's greatest heroes throughout the ages, its freezing blade able to part the hardest of armour.
This massive two-ended club is so heavy even a normal Ogre Bull would struggle. Bound into its heads is the power to shatter a boulder with one strike.
When brought down over the head, the accumulated force of several hundred tonnes of masonry explodes outward from the point of impact.
This sword is coated with a paralysing venom, a dose of which renders the victim utterly immobile.
These ancient fighting claws are believed to be the pattern upon which the Akshina modelled their weapons.
A fine sword adorned with feathers from Cathay's Vermillion War Birds.
This sword's tempered ceramic blade has been fired to a brilliant white, intensifying the cutting edge to an incandescence which seems to shear the very light itself.
Forged in the molten heat of desire and cooled in a vat of Slaanesh's own blood, the Witstealer Sword was presented to the Arch-tempter by the Dark Prince himself.
This eminent sword has a long history of slaying monsters and beasts several times bigger than its wielder.
Its blade formed from the icy spike of a Frost Wyrm, this deadly rapier finds its mark unerringly.
Simply made, but strong and flexible for a comfortable draw.
Discharging a magical blast every time it is struck, Harry’s Bane Shield rebounds his enemies blows back from whence they came.
As if driven by an unstoppable force, Harry’s hammer is blessed by the gods to hurl back the bodies and souls of those he strikes.
Strong Kislevite iron is used to make this armour.
Worn only by Kislev's greatest warriors, this embossed plate harness is inset with frost shards harder and more pure than diamonds.
The beloved Saint Annushka met her end rescuing an infant from a frozen lake. This relic from her beatified remains heals and restores its user's body.
In a major metropolis, it's all too easy to end up with a knife in your back.
The lone Bounty Hunter can go places that ungainly military units cannot.
Many Kossars leave the constant wars of their homeland to become mercenaries and adventurers elsewhere.
When the war never ends, there is always a need for fighting men.
Even a small amount of training can be the difference between life and death on the blood-soaked battlefields of the Old World.
Men fight better when their livelihood, not just their lives, is at stake.
Rob from the rich and give to the poor. That's the theory, anyway.
Experienced outdoorsmen who reconnoitre for armies, caravans, and other travelling parties. Life expectancy is short.
Professional bully wanted. Fair prices paid for beating the right people up.
Never do an honest day's work if you can avoid it.
For the scullion, stable boy, and serving wench, escape from their hard lives often seems impossible - because generally it is.
Full-time, paid professionals to man the fortresses, patrol the borders, and repel invaders.
In the criminal underworld, strength and viciousness are highly-prized virtues.
Collecting money for the government is a thankless job. Doing so in the midst of the wilderness is practically a death sentence…
Who wants to wake up in the same village or city every day, doing the same thing as yesterday? No? Thought not.
Responsible for the grooming, wardrobe, and presentation of their charges, a valet is indispensable for the style-conscious noble.
From history to anatomy to science to nothing more than the bottom of a bottle…
This old Ungol mother has accompanied the expedition despite her advanced age. She is an expert forager, always finding healing herbs no matter the terrain.
A halfling recruited in Erengrad. Every night he has managed to cook something edible with meagre rations, even if the Kvas barrels do keep getting lighter…
Sent with the expedition to map the lands far beyond Kislev's borders, should he return to the Motherland, the charts will be of great value.
The agents of the Tzarina cannot be everywhere at once.
This man deals with the day to day running of his employer's stanitsa, ensuring everything – and everyone – works properly.
One day, they hope, it may be their honour to wield the blade, rather than simply fetch it.
This one's father has entrusted their martial education to a great warrior of the Motherland.
The nomadic peoples of the north-eastern steppes are expert horsemen and masters of fighting in the saddle.
Observe the rituals and you shall be blessed and worthy of this great Motherland.
Those who scrape a living tending livestock on the steppes know the warning signs of an invading force, and can give fair warning to the authorities.
It's a dirty job that no one wants to do, but nevertheless must be done, lest the state fall into penury.
Let me tell you a tale of the last time the Dark Gods invaded the Motherland. That was a fight to behold…
A junior member of the Great Orthodoxy, not welcomed by the Ungols, he insisted on coming by Kostaltyn's order to look after the spiritual wellbeing of the troops.
An experienced scout, perhaps with Far-Northern blood in his veins, will be able to guide Yuri to Dervingard and beyond.
Not always liked by the troops, but his stinginess has made camp supplies last far longer than they should.
A clear crystal broach of purest clarity whose core dances with whirling white specks.
A phial of soil taken from the ground around the gates of Praag, infused with the blood of her heroic fallen defenders.
Smelted from a fallen star found on the snowy steppes, the metal of this ring is dark and cold.
The frost shard blade of this revered weapon sparkles with the cold, hard promise of sharp slaughter.
The sword known as Wolfbane, taken from Skollden, tainted by dark power.
Some Marauders walk openly within the lands of other races, not seen as a threat but a northern foreigner - a barbarian. But they are wrong, he is a threat.
There are many monsters in the northern wastes - creatures that will eat a man no matter which god he worships. A tribe's Beast Tamer can bring such monsters to heel… if he has the talent.
Some nobles of the mortal nations - the rich ones - take to buying antiquities and cursed items. Their ignorance in unearthing such relics is our ally.
The servants of Chaos are more than the barbarous Northmen - throughout the mortal realms secret cults worship the true Gods, and so our plans advance.
Said to have come from the ruins of Mordheim, Darksouls do not age and await the return of the Daemons that once possessed them.
Listen brave men of the Empire - pray! But not to Sigmar, he cares not for YOU. There are other Gods who are willing to answer your prayers...
Huscarls are Norse tribesmen that honourably serve their Chieftain - a manservant and shieldbearer both.
The Kurgan are a tribe that could end all others - such are their numbers. Best keep this Chieftain as an ally.
The Magister - or whatever name a cult leader abides by - is a powerful, covert agent of Chaos, tending to flocks of the corrupted within the mortal lands.
Mutants are shunned by so-called civilised societies but welcomed by the tribes of the north... and their omnipotent patrons.
Stroke, stroke - keep up or I'll feed yer to the Blood God's hounds!
There are souls that have been truly blessed by the Gods - not quite Spawn - but have received many gifts nonetheless.
The Slave Master takes the thralls taken on the raids and prepares them for bloody sacrifice or, even worse, a grisly life of servitude.
I am my master's tool - my God's vessel. Use me!

Manticores are huge leonine beasts with the wings of a giant bat and tails that drip with poison. They are the fiercest of all Chaotic mounts.

A crude effigy and shamanic heirloom from one of the hag trees that grow deep in the forest.
A potent sacrificial tool that radiates the wrath of a thousand different offerings to the Dark Gods.
The bleached skull of the long-dead Great Bray-Shaman, Rarkos, is mounted upon the bearer's staff.
This staff, and wielder, are crawling with bugs and other nasties that can be sent forth on a whim.
This battered suit of ramshackle plate mail is covered with the soot from man's burned palaces and temples.
A rotting pelt, shrouded in dark tendrils of malice that only the bravest or foolish should wear.
A headdress with two great ram horns that meld into the wearer's own, allowing him to deliver a devastating head-butt!
This ancient suit of chainmail can counter the fanciful enchantments and magicks of enemy blades.
Trollhide confers some of the more gruesome abilities of its former occupant to the wearer!
When this ancient, fossilised horn is sounded a cloud of disarray falls upon the enemy but emboldens the Gors.
These cursed items are all manner of blasphemy, from skulls of dead priests to hallowed, torn branches of Loren.
A sliver of strangely glowing stone that when cast to the ground will generate a tremendous gust of magical wind.
As a speaker of spells and caster of magicks, a Bray-Shaman can summon a magical servant to aid him in his darkling duties.
This hound doesn't reside with the others, it remains close to the Chieftain, a dangerous pet desperate to please its master.
Female Beastmen are rare. Oft-timid beasts, they carry the true-horn's seed and mother the next generation.
This Gor is skilled with flint knife able to separate skin from flesh, whether the subject is dead or still breathing.
This harpy is loyal to the Chieftain, and will break through the tree canopy to fly high and spy out the land.
Some Gors are tasked to look after the herdstones, their reward oft-being sacrifice at the stone they kept in life.
Some Beastmen are mongrels with minor mutations. Though they live their pathetic lives amongst men, their true loyalty is to the herd.
Pestigors are diseased Beastmen with rotting horns and blemished skin, oft-shunned by the herd and sent to bring Ruin.
Chaos Spawn are not easy to control and corral, but some Gors are deft at doing just that.
This scrawny Ungor is kept collared and close to the Chieftain - attending his needs, carrying his food, getting kicked and beaten.
This banner takes the form of a legendary standard torn from the grip of its dying owner and desecrated.
Once a proud standard of one of mankind’s petty nations; it is now a wretched trophy blessed with all the Dark Gods’ malice and vainglory.
This standard - an ever-rotting corpse beset by carrion birds - is a gross mockery of a scarecrow.
This ancient banner is stitched together with sinew from the skins of defeated enemies.
A jagged spike with the corroded remains of armoured warriors impaled upon it; this totem spreads an aura of entropy.

When the Banebeast Khorgor was finally slain, his powerful, half-sentient axes went missing shortly after.

Made to fell the Mammuts of the far north, this spear bears enchantments that allow it to penetrate deep into flesh.

A loyal hound, tried, tested and as much a killer as any bow-armed Elf.
